author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In this research article by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen, the authors model the epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over the last two months. This disease has unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the effects of implemented quarantine and control measures.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (
post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.As of February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan may end in late March, in the rest of China by mid March, and in the tier-one cities before early March. China is estimated to have a total of 80,511 infected individuals, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and 13,322 in other regions. These estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. We recommend maintaining strict quarantine measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. Our model can also assist other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran, in predicting and managing the epidemic. The SUQC model was developed to analyze the unique characteristics of COVID-19, such as high infectivity during incubation and the impact of control measures. This model can provide valuable insights for countries facing similar challenges.
original_pre_context: y 2020, 8(1): 11–19 https://doi.org/10.1007/s40484-020-0199-0 RESEARCH ARTICLE Modeling the epidemic dynamics and control of COVID-19 outbreak in China Shilei Zhao1,2,3, Hua Chen1,2,3,4,* 1 CAS Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101, China 2 China National Center for Bioinformation, Beijing 100101, China 3 School of Future Technology, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China 4 CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Kunming 650223, China * Correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn Received February 29, 2020; Revised March 4, 2020; Accepted March 4, 2020 Background: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over last two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (
original_post_context: ), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Note that the estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Conclusions: We suggest that rigorous quarantine and control measures should be kept before early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, and before late March in Hubei. The model can also be useful to predict the trend of epidemic and provide quantitative guide for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy and Iran. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model Author summary: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over last two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily numbers of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of quarantine and control measures. We developed a SUQC model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19. SUQC is applied to the daily released data of China to predict the trend of epidemic. SUQC can also provide quantitative guidance for other countries in a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
RESEARCH ARTICLE: Tracking and Controlling the Spread of COVID-19 in Japan

Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen

Various distinct characteristics set the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) apart from other infectious diseases. These include its high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between the actual spread and the daily reported number of cases, and the impact of quarantine and control efforts. The rapid spread of COVID-19 in Japan and more than 30 other countries over the past two months highlights the urgent need for effective modeling and control measures.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.The estimated number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 was 3,509, decreasing to 334 on February 21, 2020. Based on this data, it is predicted that COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei will end around late March, mid-March for Japan excluding Hubei, and before early March for the tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, with the majority in Wuhan. Quarantine and control measures should be upheld until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Fukuoka, and until late March in Hubei. The SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and can also be useful in predicting the trend of the epidemic in other countries at high risk of outbreak.

COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), China (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of China. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (
original_post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Note that the estimates are from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Conclusions: We suggest that rigorous quarantine and control measures should be kept before early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, and before late March in Hubei. The model can also be useful to predict the trend of epidemic and provide quantitative guide for other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy and Iran. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model Author summary: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries over last two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily numbers of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of quarantine and control measures. We developed a SUQC model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19. SUQC is applied to the daily released data of China to predict the trend of epidemic. SUQC can also provide quantitative guidance for other countries in a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Contact me at chenh@big.ac.cn. I received this document on February 29, 2020, revised it on March 4, 2020, and accepted it on the same day. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been spreading rapidly in China and over 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and the daily reported number of cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.

To analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, we developed a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model that explicitly accounts for the effects of interventions. This model is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models.

Applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we analyzed the COVID-19 outbreak in Chengdu, Sichuan (excluding Chengdu), China (excluding Sichuan), and four first-tier cities in China. Our findings show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. After January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that quarantine and control measures have been effective in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Chengdu estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Sichuan excluding Chengdu (0.1914), and that of China excluding Sichuan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Chengdu on February 12, 2020, is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Chengdu and Sichuan is around late March, around mid-March for China excluding Sichuan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Chengdu, 17,679 from Sichuan (excluding Chengdu), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Sichuan). The provided estimates stem from a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. The recommendations are to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Sichuan. This model can also be beneficial for predicting the trajectory of the epidemic and offering quantitative guidance for other high-risk countries such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and numerous other countries in the past couple of months. It possesses unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, time lag between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. The SUQC model has been developed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and is being utilized with China's daily data to forecast the epidemic trend and can also offer guidance for other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Received on February 29, 2020, revised on March 4, 2020, and accepted on the same date, this article discusses the rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in China and over 30 other countries in the past two months. The unique characteristics of COVID-19, such as high infectivity during the incubation period and the efficacy of quarantine and control measures, distinguish it from other infectious diseases. To better understand the dynamics of COVID-19, the authors developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model that explicitly considers the effects of intervention measures. By applying this model to data from the outbreak in various regions of China, the study shows that the implementation of quarantine and control measures has been effective in reducing the reproductive number of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Jiangsu excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Jiangsu (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Jiangsu is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Jiangsu, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Jiangsu (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Jiangsu).Please be aware that the estimates presented in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and therefore may contain some uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Jiangsu to effectively combat the spread of COVID-19. This model can also be utilized to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance to countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The characteristics of COVID-19, including its high infectivity during incubation and the time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, make it distinct from other infectious diseases. Our SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to data from China to predict the epidemic trend. This model can also provide valuable guidance for other countries at risk of outbreak. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020, the COVID-19 outbreak has been rapidly spreading in Japan and numerous other countries for the past two months. This disease presents unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. To better understand this situation, we have devised a model known as Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) to study the dynamics of COVID-19 and assess the effects of intervention strategies. By applying this model to data from various regions in Japan, we have observed that the implementation of quarantine and control measures has been effective in reducing the reproductive number R below 1 after January 30th, 2020, indicating a decline in the spread of the virus.The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for Japan excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei).Estimates from a deterministic ODE model indicate that there is some uncertainty in the data. It is recommended that strict quarantine and control measures are maintained in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hubei until late March. The model can also be used to predict the epidemic trend and provide guidance for countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Japan and other countries, with unique characteristics that include high infectivity during incubation and time delays in reporting daily cases. A SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and provide guidance for epidemic prediction in Japan and other countries. text: The total number of infected individuals is estimated to be 49,510
author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In Fig. 1B, a significant gap is evident between the predicted total infections and confirmed infections in Hubei, China, with clinical diagnosis adopted as an additional criterion after February 14. This resulted in a notable increase in confirmed infections due to a higher confirmation rate. However, a proportion of total infected individuals remain unidentified even with clinical diagnosis. Long-term predictions of total infected, unquarantined infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed infections in Hubei, China, were plotted based on inferred parameters (Fig. 1A). The predicted end time for the epidemic is 147 days from January 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals. Analyzing stage I data from Hubei, China showed a dramatic increase in predicted numbers of infected individuals compared to observed numbers after January 21, indicating the importance of rigorous quarantine and control measures against the epidemic trend. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Hubei, China and clinical diagnosis was adopted after February 14, we also analyzed the stage III data (from February 14). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.
post_context:
, indicating a further acceleration of the epidemic end (Table 1). An analysis was conducted on stage I and II data of Hubei province (excluding Hubei, China), the whole country (excluding Hubei, China), and four tier-1 cities in China (Figs. 2 and 3; Supplementary Figs. S1–S4; Tables 1 and 2). The model predictions were found to be highly accurate, showing similar trends across these regions. The differences in predicted numbers of infected individuals between the two stages of data highlight the importance and effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. Notably, even with stage I data, Beijing demonstrated a reproductive number lower than 1, indicating a timely and effective response to COVID-19.

The confirmation rate in Hubei, China was significantly lower than in other regions, with the city having the highest number of infected individuals exceeding local clinical resources. This led to long wait times for confirmation and the lowest confirmation rate of all regions. By February 11, 2020, the model predicted that 26,810 quarantined infections in Hubei, China had not been confirmed. However, after February 14 when clinical diagnosis was implemented, the confirmation rate in Hubei, China increased.

The data also revealed differences in quarantine rates and reproductive numbers between Hubei, China (excluding Hubei, China), and the rest of China. The model provided parameter estimations for the epidemic dynamics in each region, showing variations in quarantine rates, reproductive numbers, and confirmation rates at different stages of the outbreak.
original_pre_context: e also plotted in Fig. 1B. We can see big gap between the predicted numbers of total infections and the predicted numbers of confirmed infections in Wuhan. Clinical diagnosis is adopted by Wuhan local medical agency as an additional diagnosis criterion after Feb 12, increasing the confirmation rate and causing a big boost of the number of confirmed infections. Note that a proportion of the total infected still remains unidentified even with clinical diagnosis. With the inferred parameters, we further plot the longterm predictions of the numbers of total infected (I), unquarantined infected (U ), quarantined infected (Q) and cumulative confirmed infections (C) in Wuhan (Fig. 1A). The end time (increment of confirmed infections equals zero) is predicted to be 147 days from Jan 28, 2020. The total number of infected individuals is 62,577 (Table 1). We can do a similar analysis using stage I data of Wuhan. The stage I data is informative for predicting the epidemic trend assuming no rigorous quarantine and control measures. The first 10 daily data points (from Jan 20) were used to infer the parameters. The rest data points were used to test the performance of the model (Fig. 1C, D). As clearly seen in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of CðtÞ and IðtÞ increase dramatically, which are far beyond the observed numbers after Jan 21. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Wuhan and clinical diagnosis was adopted after Feb 12, we also analyzed the stage III data (from Feb 13). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In Figure 1C, the projected counts of C(t) and I(t) show a significant increase, far surpassing the actual numbers after January 21. The total number of infections could reach as high as 8,923,823, with the outbreak lasting a much longer period (328 days, as shown in Table 1). The stark contrast between projections from stage I and stage II data by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen suggests that measures like travel restrictions and quarantine have been highly effective in curbing the spread of the epidemic. With more stringent quarantine protocols and traffic controls implemented post-February 12, along with the introduction of clinical diagnosis, an analysis of stage III data (from February 13) was conducted. The estimated quarantine rate was found to be 0.6185, considerably higher than the estimate based on stage II data (0.3917). The projected total number of infected individuals was 49,510, indicating a further hastening of the epidemic's conclusion (refer to Table 1). Similar assessments were carried out for stage I and II data from Hunan province (excluding Wuhan), the rest of the country (excluding Hunan), and four major cities in China (as depicted in Figures 2 and 3; Supplementary Figures S1–S4; Tables 1 and 2). Overall, the model's predictions have shown a high level of accuracy. A consistent pattern emerged across these areas: the projected infection numbers differed markedly between the two stages, underscoring the importance and effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. Notably, even with stage I data, Beijing exhibited a reproductive number below 1 (as shown in Supplementary Figure S1; Table 2, 0.8840), indicating a rapid and efficient response to COVID-19 at an early stage.From Figs. 2 and 3, Supplementary Figs. S1–S4, we notice that the difference between CðtÞ and IðtÞ in Wuhan is the biggest. Wuhan has the most infected individuals than any other places in China (more than 50%), highly beyond the limit of local clinical resources, leading to a long waiting time for confirmation, and the lowest confirmation rate of 0.0643 in Wuhan, compared with
post_context: of Hunan (excluding Wuhan), 0.2189 of China (excluding Hunan), 0.2680 of Beijing, 0.2846 of Shanghai, 0.2871 of Guangzhou, and 0.2599 of Shenzhen.According to the model, as of February 11, 2020, 26,810 quarantined infections in Wuhan have not been confirmed. The confirmation rate in Wuhan increased to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical diagnosis was implemented. The table shows parameter estimations for epidemic dynamics in Wuhan, Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and China (excluding Hunan) in terms of quarantine rate, reproductive number, and confirmation rate. The numbers indicate the end time for different stages of the epidemic.

The reproductive number in Hubei city decreases from 0.7575 in stage II to 0.4797 in stage III, indicating that the epidemic in China is being effectively controlled. Un-quarantined individuals serve as the primary source of new infections. According to data from stage II, there are still estimated to be 3,509 un-quarantined individuals in Hubei city as of Feb 12 (Fig.1A), and person-to-person transmission is expected to continue until mid-May 2020. However, based on data from stage III, the quarantine rate in Hubei city increases to 0.6185 and the number of unquarantined infected individuals decreases to 334 by Feb 21, 2020 (Fig.1E). Predictions made after analyzing data from stage II and stage III suggest that the COVID-19 outbreak in China will likely end in late March for Hubei city and Hubei (excluding Hubei city), and by mid-March for China as a whole. The four first-tier cities (Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen) are expected to see the end of the outbreak before early March. The end of the outbreak with zero un-quarantined infections is typically earlier than with zero new confirmed infections.

In this model, infected individuals go directly to confirmed cases, or indirectly through quarantine. This can be simplified by eliminating the direct path, resulting in Eq. 2. The model includes parameters such as the mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation (T) and the mean time delay from isolation to confirmation (w). The reproductive number of the infection can be defined as R=α=g1. Parameter inference is typically based on the number of confirmed infections (CðtÞ), which is observed daily. The initial values of susceptible individuals (Sð0Þ) and confirmed infections (Cð0Þ) are determined by the population size and official reports, respectively.Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. Estimating the parameter α accurately is challenging, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 based on different methods or data sets. Weighted loss functions are explored to better integrate information across the epidemic.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Taking uncertainties in data into account is an essential aspect of modelling, where data at each time point is treated as following a probability distribution with a mean specified by the assumed model and a variance determined by the assumed probability distribution. The relationship between data and model predictions is a critical issue, with confirmed cases representing only a portion of the total infected population. A useful analogy is comparing the visible tip of an iceberg (confirmed cases) to the larger, hidden portion below the surface (total infected population), often referred to as the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2019). Why might this present a challenge for modelers? During model calibration, in order to determine important model parameters like the transmission rate (b), the model output must be adjusted by the case-infection ratio (r) to accurately predict confirmed case data. By varying the ratio r, different values for the transmission rate b can be calculated, affecting the basic reproduction number (R0), epidemic scale, and peak time. Due to the wide range of possible case-infection ratios for COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary widely, resulting in a range of model predictions. This variability is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling field, where different combinations of parameters can produce similar data fits but divergent predictions about the epidemic. Addressing nonidentifiability during model calibration is crucial for ensuring the reliability of predictions. Conventional methods like nonlinear least squares may struggle to address this issue effectively, as they rely on basic optimization algorithms that may not account for the multitude of possible global minima.
original_pre_context: already take into consideration uncertainties in data by allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean given by the assumed model and the variance t given by the assumed probability distribution, where the variance may depend on the mean. The lack of data, as we will demonstrate, is a more serious concern for modellers. A key issue that can explain the variability in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) compares with model predictions. Confirmed cases are people with symptoms who made contact with a hospital, got tested, and whose infection of COVID-19 was confirmed by DNA or imaging tests. The infected compartment in by transmission models represents all people who are infected. These include people who may or may not have symptoms and contacts with a hospital, as well as people with confirmed laboratory tests and those who are misdiagnosed. In this sense, confirmed cases (data) are only a fraction of the total infected population (model predictions). A metaphor of an iceberg best represents the difference between data and model predictions. The entire iceberg represents the total infected population, and the tip of the iceberg above the sea surface represents the case data. The part of the iceberg hidden under the water represents the infected people that are unknown to public health surveillance and testing; often called the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2019e2020, the
original_post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2020). Why should this be a problem for the modellers? In model calibration, in order to estimate key model parameters such as the transmission rate b, by fitting the model output to the confirmed cases data, it is necessary to discount the total number of infectious people, IðtÞ, from the model prediction, by the case-infection ratio r to appropriately predict confirmed case data. For each value of the ratio r, a corresponding value for the transmission rate b can then be estimated by fitting the model to data, which in turn determines the basic reproduction number R 0, the scale of the epidemic, as well as the peak time. Given the potential wide range for the case-infection ratio r of the COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b has a wide range, and hence the wide range of reported model predictions. In modeling terms, given the confirmed-case data, there is a linkage between the model parameter r and the transmission rate b, and potentially also with other model parameters. While many different combinations of r and b can show good fit to the data, they can produce very different model predictions of the epidemic. This is known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, see e.g. (Lintusaari, Gutmann, Kaski, & Corander, 2016; Raue et al., 2009; van der Vaart, 1998). It means that a group of model parameters can not be uniquely determined from the given data during model calibration. Different choices of parameter values with the same good fit to the data can lead to very different model predictions. The ways in which nonidentifiability is addressed in the model calibration process greatly influences the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is known to be ill suited to detect or address the nonidentifiability issue, since it relies on a rudimentary optimization algorithm. These rudimentary optimization algorithms attempt to find a global minimum of the given objective function, but there are infinitely many global minima g

Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Nanjing, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Nanjing, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a compartment known as E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet infectious, reflecting the realistic biological phenomenon of a latent period in COVID-19 infection that can last up to 14 days. This means that newly infected individuals may not be contagious while the virus is still incubating in their bodies. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the onset of clinical symptoms such as fever and cough. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model is more biologically realistic, but it requires estimation of two additional parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Both models have negligible deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments during the prediction period. The differential equations for each model are provided, and model calibration is done using newly confirmed case data matching the corresponding terms in both models. The impact of deaths in the R compartment on model fitting is not considered due to the focus on confirmed cases for calibration.

The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious on average two days after the onset of symptoms WHO (2003); so, the SARS latent period is on average longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. The transfer diagrams for both models are shown in Fig. 1. The biological meaning of all model parameters are given in Table 1 and Table 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths occurring in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions. (4 months). Since we use the newly confirmed case data for model calibration, which is matched to the rI term in both models, the death term in the R compartment has no effect on our model fitting. post_context: . In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet infectious. This latency in COVID-19 infection is realistic due to a potential 14-day incubation period, during which newly infected individuals may not be spreading the virus. It is important to differentiate between the latent period (time from infection to infectiousness) and the incubation period (time from infection to symptom onset). While individuals with SARS become infectious around two days after symptoms appear, evidence suggests that those with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms. The SEIR model, although more biologically accurate, has the disadvantage of including two unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we note the difference between the latent period, which is the period from the time an individual is infected to the time the individual is infectious, and the incubation period, which is the period between the time an individual is infected to the time clinical symptoms appear, which include fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious on average two days after the onset of symptoms WHO (2003); so, the SARS latent period is on average longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence has shown that infected individuals can be infectious before the onset of symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the length of the latent period is largely unknown. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model has the strength of being more biologically realistic, but the SEIR model has the drawback of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. author: enrique
pre_context: Using data from various sources such as epidemiological, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. This can be challenging when dealing with outbreaks of unknown pathogens in real time, like with SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19 pandemic. An alternative approach is to improve inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting process, using Bayesian inference along with the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this objective. Baseline predictions for Hubei Province, China and three scenarios were generated, with prediction intervals based on sampling the posterior distribution. The parameter values and credible intervals are provided in Table 1, utilizing newly confirmed cases reported between January 21 and February 4, 2020. These projections offer insight into the potential epidemic in Hubei Province, China if additional control measures were not implemented after February 7, including increased hospital beds and door-to-door visits for quarantine. Figures 4(a) and (b) depict the projected peak time and estimated values for the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hubei Province, China together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 7.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimation, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases would be around 120,000 and the epidemic in Hubei Province, China would continue until mid-May 2020.
original_pre_context: nical, surveillance, or administrative data, and from published literature, that can be used for model calibration. This approach is often difficult when facing an outbreak of unknown pathogens that occur in real time such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another approach is to adopt better inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow done the otherwise large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm was able to achieve this objective. 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios Our baseline predictions for Wuhan are prediction intervals produced by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. The best-fit parameter values and credible intervals are shown in Table 1. The Bayesian inference used the newly confirmed cases for Wuhan contained in the official reports from January 21 to February 4, 2020. This is the period during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Wuhan, but before the further control measures that were undertaken in Wuhan after February 7, 2020, including the drastic increase in the available hospital beds and the door-to-door visits used to identify and quarantine suspected cases. These projections show our estimation for the hypothetical epidemic in Wuhan if further control measures after February 7 were not implemented. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), we show the distributions of the projected peak time and the estimated values of the control reproduction number R c. In Fig. 4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Wuhan together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 23 - March 6.
original_post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. By our projection, without the strict quarantine measures after February 7, the peak case total would reach approximately 120; 000, and the epidemic in Wuhan would not be over before mid-May of 2020.

pre_context:
Therefore, it is important for the user to adjust this parameter based on local epidemic data, as detailed in Section 2.6.8. The value of β varies depending on the type of contact when incorporating a realistic network structure including households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts. The default transmission probabilities are around 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for community contacts. These values were chosen based on research findings and time-use surveys to provide a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a population without different network layers. Without interventions, transmission events typically occur 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. The β value can be adjusted by interventions such as physical distancing. We also consider individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness by modeling individual viral load.

Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape

The daily viral load plays a role in adjusting the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual each day. Figure 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The percentage of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the situation; estimates for Seattle are provided in [25]. Research has conflicting findings on whether transmissibility is reduced when the infected person does not display symptoms [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not lower, but we have a parameter that can be adjusted based on the specific modeling scenario or context. It is worth noting that some studies have suggested much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].

If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values correspond to relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, chosen (a) for consistency with both time-use surveys [53] and studies of infections with known contact types [47], and (b) to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population (i.e., if different network layers are not used). When combined with the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, for a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the proportions of transmission events that occur in each contact layer in the absence of interventions are approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be modified by interventions, such as physical distancing, as described below. In addition to allowing individuals to differ in terms of disease severity and time spent in each disease state, we allow individual infectiousness to vary between people and over time. We use individual viral load to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58].
